Context:
Apprenticeships are regulated by the Ministry of Labour, Immigration, Training and Skills Development (MLITSD). The training offers industry-specific education through a combination of on-the-job and in-school learning experiences. George Brown College provides support for various groups including women, new immigrants, residents of marginalized communities, aboriginal peoples, consumer survivors, and rural area residents through pre-apprenticeship programs, though these programs are not currently available.

The college has a Disabilities Services Office at each campus, providing physical access to people with mobility/functional impairments and accommodations for those with disabilities, mental health concerns, Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder, Acquired Brain Injury, medical conditions (such as Epilepsy, HIV, Diabetes, Kidney Disease), and to persons who are deaf, deafened or hard of hearing or who have low vision or blindness.

Essential Employability Skills are critical components of the programs at George Brown College. These skills include:
- Communication
- Time management
- Problem solving
- Teamwork
- Adaptability
- Organizational skills
- Workplace safety
- Building relationships
- Customer service
- Numeracy
- Information technology
- Planning and prioritizing
- Professionalism
- Quality control

Apprenticeships take between two to five years to complete. During the first year, apprentices earn a minimum of forty percent of what a journeyperson mentor is paid.
